abstract: Trimming General Electric’s finance unit to narrow its focus and its balance sheet is no easy task.
snippet: Trimming General Electric’s finance unit to narrow its focus and its balance sheet is no easy task.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that Jeffrey R. Immelt, chief executive of General Electric, could remake the conglomerate’s troubled finance unit, GE Capital, from scratch. Ideally he would narrow its focus to businesses related to G.E.’s core industrial strengths  and the size of its balance sheet to about $360 billion in assets. Imagining, though, illustrates just how difficult it will be to tame GE Capital to a manageable size.

abstract: Imagine that Jeffrey R. Immelt, chief executive of General Electric, could remake the conglomerate’s troubled finance unit, GE Capital, from scratch, Breakingviews says.
snippet: Imagine that Jeffrey R. Immelt, chief executive of General Electric, could remake the conglomerate’s troubled finance unit, GE Capital, from scratch, Breakingviews says.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that Jeffrey R. Immelt, chief executive of General Electric, could remake the conglomerate’s troubled finance unit, GE Capital, from scratch. Ideally he would narrow its focus to businesses related to G.E.’s core industrial strengths — and the size of its balance sheet to about $360 billion in assets, Reuters Breakingviews suggests. Imagining, though, illustrates just how difficult it will be to tame GE Capital to a manageable size.
